Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Provably Correct Control Software for Autonomous High-Performance Agents

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to investigate a rigorous approach to control software certification for multi-task agents with complex dynamics. The analysis tools stem from a novel treatment of integral quadratic constraint (IQC) based uncertainty analysis, and can handle hybrid non-stationary parameter-dependent control systems and a wide range of uncertainties. These tools provide, at the algorithmic level, a sophisticated method for validation of control systems by determining ellipsoids that are invariant under task-based state transitions. The same analysis tools will be utilized to generate annotated control program code based on the Floyd-Hoare paradigm, migrating in the process high-level, systemic properties down to the executable code. The annotated code can then be checked for correctness by using a theorem prover augmented with appropriate theories. Modules stemming from the IQC-based analysis will be introduced into existing, public domain autocoders to enable high-level annotations with properties. The approach will be implemented on an uninhabited aerial vehicle (UAV) platform.

If successful, the research will apply to complex high-performance systems such as UAVs operating autonomously in dynamic environments and sharing space with humans and human-piloted vehicles. The formal validation approach can be applied before the physical prototype is tested or even built, promising reductions in time and cost of the software development process and an expedited transition of technology to practice. This formal validation also leads to formal safety guarantees, tackling one of the critical barriers to the integration of autonomous vehicles into civil society. The integration of research and education will be achieved through the UAV testbed, which will be utilized to construct educational modules and provide a hands-on environment for courses and undergraduate research. The educational modules will be communicated to pre-college students, including women and minorities, through outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on developing a rigorous mathematical approach for validation of control systems of high-performance multi-task agents. To this end, we developed integral quadratic constraint (IQC) based analysis tools rooted in dissipativity arguments that can handle discrete-time linear time-varying nominal systems with uncertain initial conditions and allow for the use of time-varying IQC multipliers, time-varying signal IQC multipliers, and performance criteria defined in terms of time-domain, time-varying IQCs. We demonstrated how these tools can be used to better characterize modeling uncertainties and disturbance inputs, thereby significantly reducing the conservativeness of the analysis outcomes, and how they can give valuable results that can be used by practitioners, such as point-wise bounds on the performance outputs. We provided a number of novel time-varying IQC multipliers and signal IQC multipliers that describe time-domain phenomena. We also developed complementary computational tools for solving the discrete-time IQC analysis problem and demonstrated how to extend some of the developed results for robustness analysis to uncertain time-varying systems interconnected over arbitrary graphs.

Our theoretical analysis results apply for general time-varying systems and are expressed in terms of an infinite sequence of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). If the nominal system and multipliers are eventually periodic, we showed that the existence of a general time-varying solution sequence to the attendant LMIs is equivalent to the existence of an eventually periodic solution sequence. Such an equivalence allows one to search for an eventually periodic solution sequence via a finite dimensional semidefinite program without the concern of introducing conservatism. Eventually periodic linear time-varying systems include linear time-invariant, periodic linear time-varying, and finite horizon linear systems as special cases.

We also demonstrated the utility of IQC analysis in investigating the robustness of fixed-wing unmanned aircraft system (UAS) controllers. Specifically, we developed an uncertain UAS framework to aid in the certification of UAS flight controllers, whereby the UAS is modeled using a linear fractional transformation on uncertainties and then robustness analysis is conducted on the uncertain system via IQC theory. This uncertain UAS framework accounts for uncertainties in the actuator, aerodynamic, and dynamic models and incorporates uncertainties in the UAS trim point. The latter allows the application of IQC analysis for level, arbitrarily curved paths whose inverse radius of curvature is bounded. We demonstrated how to use IQC analysis to tune a variety of path-following and trajectory-tracking controllers. By comparing IQC analysis results, simulations, and flight tests of numerous controllers, we showed that IQC analysis is a useful tool in predicting controller failures and qualitatively comparing the performance of controllers. We also demonstrated that signal IQCs have an important role in obtaining IQC analysis results that are less conservative and more consistent with observations from flight test data. Furthermore, we showed that with minor modifications this framework is transferable to other autonomous systems, such as autonomous underwater vehicles.

Last, we demonstrated how to use compositional reasoning for verified design of single as well as multiple complex cyber-physical systems. The novelty of our work is in showing how an established composability framework can be used for design of complex systems such as UAS. To do so, we had to enhance the capabilities of the original framework by employing tools beyond formal methods that help prove local component properties. Specifically, our work demonstrates how results from robust control theory and Euclidean geometry can be utilized to prove logical implications about component properties/specifications which are otherwise difficult to prove using methods such as model checking and theorem proving. 

Five PhD students contributed to this research, and four undergraduate students worked on tasks pertinent to the project. A new graduate special topics course on formal analysis of software systems was developed and offered. Almost every year of the project, the PI and his group participated in summer activities organized by Virginia Tech's Center for the Enhancement of Engineering Diversity. These activities were targeted toward middle school and high school students, with the aim of increasing the participation/success of students from underrepresented groups in science and engineering. For these activities, lectures and participatory experiments were prepared, tackling topics such as flight mechanics and the safe operation of autonomous UAS.
